Define the Product Model Data Specification for the TracWater Mini Buoy, including raw data, MODBUS registers, data conversion methods, raw data assets and portal data definitions required by the TracWater IAAS platform.
This specification applies to all TracWater Mini Buoy deployments that use a multiparameter sonde connected via a MQTT MODBUS Gateway to the TracWater IAAS platform.

content.text: Product: TracWater Mini Buoy
Raw data specification

The TracWater Mini Buoy acquires and transmits real-time water-quality data from surface water bodies using an integrated chain of sensors, gateways, and cloud-based infrastructure. The data flow begins at the immersed multiparameter sonde and continues through to the TracWater IAAS platform, where measurements are stored, processed, analysed, and ultimately presented to customers through online portals, alarm notifications, and automated exception reports.
Subsequent sections describe each stage of this flow in detail, from local sensor acquisition to the cloud-based interpretation and presentation of results.

subsections.title: TracWater Mini Buoy – Data Flow Overview (Text Diagram)

Downstream Flow:

    • IAAS decodes MQTT responses ↠ engineering units via MODBUS Map & 

      Conversion Methods (IEEE 754, ASCII etc.)

    • Data stored in Time-Series DB ↠ processed datasets ↠ portal visualisation

      ↠ alarms ↠ reports ↠ API outputs

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The multiparameter sonde is equipped with a range of water-quality sensors (e.g. dissolved oxygen, pH, temperature, turbidity, oxidation-reduction potential). Each measurement is stored within the sonde’s internal MODBUS RS-485 registers.
The sonde operates as a MODBUS slave device, identified by a unique MODBUS ID, and continuously maintains updated measurement values in its holding registers.

Although the sonde is physically connected to the MQTT MODBUS Gateway via RS-485, the gateway functions purely as a protocol bridge between the RS-485 bus and the MQTT broker. The gateway does not act as the MODBUS master.

The TracWater IAAS server application assumes the logical role of the MODBUS master, generating MODBUS read requests that are encapsulated within MQTT messages. These requests pass through the MQTT MODBUS Gateway, which transparently relays them to the sonde and returns the retrieved register data to the broker for collection by TracWater IAAS.
The multiparameter sonde connects via a hard-wired RS-485 link to a MQTT MODBUS Gateway (e.g. Teltonika TRB145).

The gateway serves as a network bridge that enables legacy MODBUS RTU slave devices to be queried by modern, server-based MODBUS master software over an IP network. It provides a translation layer between RS-485 MODBUS RTU and MQTT, allowing commands originating from TracWater IAAS to reach the sonde without requiring a persistent serial connection.

In practical terms, the gateway:

Maintains the physical RS-485 connection to the sonde.

Subscribes to its assigned MQTT request topic to receive encoded MODBUS read commands.

Executes those commands locally against the sonde and publishes the results to the MQTT response topic.

Although it performs the serial query locally, the gateway does so on behalf of the TracWater IAAS application, which remains the true MODBUS master. This design provides a powerful and efficient way to make traditional RS-485 instruments securely accessible to cloud-based systems.

Each TracWater Mini Buoy is assigned a pair of MQTT topics on the MQTT Broker, distinguished by the OEM serial number of its multiparameter sonde:

<serial>/request

<serial>/response

These dedicated topics isolate message traffic per buoy, ensuring unambiguous routing of requests and responses.

The TracWater IAAS application initiates communication by publishing JSON-formatted MQTT messages to the <serial>/request topic. Each request specifies:

The configured gateway path.

The MODBUS ID of the sonde.

The register address (Base-1 format).

The number of registers to read.

A unique integer cookie for correlating responses.

Upon publication, the MQTT Broker accepts the message and makes it available for polling by the corresponding Mini Buoy gateway.

The MQTT MODBUS Gateway periodically polls the <serial>/request topic. For each message received, the gateway:

Parses the JSON request and extracts the MODBUS parameters.

Executes the MODBUS read command on the connected sonde.

Retrieves the stored register values.

Converts each register value into a signed short.

Packages the results into a JSON MQTT message and publishes it to the <serial>/response topic, preserving the same cookie value for correlation.

The TracWater IAAS system monitors each buoy’s <serial>/response topic and, for every received message:

Matches the response to its originating request using the cookie value.

Identifies the data-type category of the registers returned, based on the MODBUS map configuration for the target device.

Applies the appropriate decoding and conversion method to interpret the stored register values.

Transforms the decoded values into engineering units and applies the correct scaling, precision, and metadata.

Logs the processed measurements into the time-series database, linking each value to its originating sensor and register address.

Each MODBUS device accessible through the MQTT MODBUS Gateway has its own requirements for interpreting the binary or encoded data that it transmits. Six primary conversion categories are defined within the TracWater MODBUS map, including (but not limited to):

Floating-point (IEEE 754) registers

Byte-to-ASCII registers

Bit-code registers

Unsigned-short registers

Signed-short registers

Byte-size hexadecimal registers

TracWater IAAS automatically recognises which conversion type applies to each dataset and uses the correct decoding logic before the data can be stored, visualised, or analysed.

This structured communication process ensures:

Traceability – every measurement is linked to its physical sensor and MQTT transaction.

Integrity – cookie-based correlation prevents message mismatch.

Accuracy – IEEE-754 conversion preserves floating-point precision.

Auditability – topic-based segregation simplifies verification and troubleshooting.

The MODBUS Register Map defines every data point available for read access between the TracWater Mini Buoy’s multiparameter sonde and the TracWater IAAS application. It specifies the address, length, unit, and description of each parameter stored within the device’s internal registers.

This map applies to all TracWater Mini Buoy configurations connected via the MQTT MODBUS Gateway. It includes:

All MODBUS Read Function 0x03 registers (data acquisition).

All MODBUS Write Function 0x10 registers (device configuration and control).

The data-conversion category assigned to each register group (see Section 4.10).

The MODBUS Map is organised into categories based on the decoding method required by TracWater IAAS. Each category includes:

Data Name and Sensor Type

Base-1 and Base-0 Address

Number of Registers

Unit of Measurement

Conversion Category (see Section MODBUS Data Conversion Methods and Categories)

Description

subsections.title: MODBUS Data Conversion Methods and Categories

content.text: Each register listed in Section MODBUS Register Map includes a field titled Conversion Method (Category #), which identifies the decoding logic that the TracWater IAAS platform applies when interpreting the raw data stored within the device’s MODBUS registers.
The Conversion Method number corresponds directly to the conversion categories defined in this section.

These categories describe how different Stored Value Types (for example, 32-bit IEEE 754 floats, 16-bit shorts, bit-fields, ASCII strings, or hexadecimal codes) are translated into usable engineering values, textual identifiers, or operational statuses within the TracWater IAAS system.

By maintaining a one-to-one mapping between each register’s Conversion Method (Category #) in Section 4.9 and the decoding procedure documented in this section, the TracWater IAAS platform ensures accurate, deterministic, and auditable interpretation of all data retrieved from MODBUS devices connected via the MQTT MODBUS Gateway.
When a response message is received from the MQTT Broker, TracWater IAAS first identifies the conversion category for the relevant register block by referencing the MODBUS register map.
The system then applies the matching decoding logic to convert the raw 16-bit register data into human-readable engineering values (e.g. floats, integers, ASCII strings, or enumerated codes).
The conversion categories ensure consistent interpretation regardless of device model or firmware.
Description: Used for sensors that output 32-bit IEEE 754 floating-point values (e.g. dissolved oxygen, turbidity, conductivity, pH, temperature, salinity, oxidation-reduction potential).
Conversion Method: Combine two 16-bit signed short values, reverse the byte order (DCBA → ABCD), then convert the resulting 32-bit binary string to a float using IEEE 754 format.
Reference: See MODBUS map table – Section 1, Category 1.

Conversion example: The following example illustrates how TracWater IAAS processes a typical MQTT response message for this category.

Request message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "type": 1,

  "device_id": "sonde",

  "timeout": 1,

  "server_id": 1,

  "function": 3,

  "register_number": 9735,

  "register_count": 2

}



Response message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "success": true,

  "data": [

    -12852,

    -17343

  ]

}



Conversion:

Convert the 1st signed integer to a ‘signed short’ in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

-12852 == 1100110111001100

Convert the 2nd signed integer to a ‘signed short’ in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

-17343 == 1011110001000001

Create a 32bit binary number by appending the 2nd 16bit binary number to the end of the 1st 16bit binary number.

1100110111001100 && 1011110001000001 = 11001101110011001011110001000001

Reverse the ‘byte order’ of the 32bit binary number.

11001101110011001011110001000001 == 11001101  11001100  10111100  01000001


Becomes:
01000001  10111100  11001100  11001101 == 01000001101111001100110011001101

Use IEEE 754 floating point conversion to convert the 32bit binary number into a floating point number. Reference link.

01000001101111001100110011001101 == 23.6

Description: Used for textual identifiers such as OEM serial numbers or alphanumeric labels.
Conversion Method: Each 16-bit register contains two bytes, each representing an ASCII character. Convert and concatenate all bytes sequentially to form the final string.
Reference: MODBUS map – Section 1, Category 2.

Conversion example: The following example illustrates how TracWater IAAS processes a typical MQTT response message for this category.

Request message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "type": 1,

  "device_id": "sonde",

  "timeout": 1,

  "server_id": 1,

  "function": 3,

  "register_number": 5121,

  "register_count": 6

}


Response message example:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "success": true,

  "data": [

    22860,

    13112,

    12853,

    12337,

    12342,

    12344

  ]

} 


Conversion:

MQTT response message contains a field named “data”, which contains a list of 6 “signed integers”.

Convert the 1st signed integer to a ‘signed short’ in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

22860 == 0101100101001100

Convert the first 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 1st character. Reference link.

01011001 = Y

Convert the second 8 bits of the 16bit binary into an ASCII character to produce the 2nd character. Reference link.

01001100 = L

Convert the 2nd signed integer to a ‘signed short’ in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

13112 == 0011001100111000

Convert the first 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 3rd character. Reference link.

00110011 = 3

Convert the second 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 4th character. Reference link.

00111000 = 8

Convert the 3rd signed integer to a ‘signed short’ in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

12853 == 0011001000110101

Convert the first 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 5th character. Reference link.

00110010 = 2

Convert the second 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 6th character. Reference link.

00110101 = 5

Convert the 4th signed integer to a ‘signed short’ in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

12337 == 0011000000110001

Convert the first 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 7th character. Reference link.

00110000 = 0

Convert the second 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 8th character. Reference link.

00110001 = 1

Convert the 5th signed integer to a ‘signed short’ in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

12342 == 0011000000110110

Convert the first 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 9th character. Reference link.

00110000 = 0

Convert the second 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 10th character. Reference link.

00110110 = 6

Convert the 6th signed integer to a ‘signed short’ in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

12344 ==  0011000000111000

Convert the first 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 11th character. Reference link.

00110000 = 0

Convert the second 8 bits into an ASCII character to produce the 12th character. Reference link.

00111000 = 8

Concatenate the characters

YL3825010608

Description: Used for status or error-state indicators where individual bits represent discrete conditions or flags.
Conversion Method: Convert the 16-bit register to binary form, evaluate each bit according to the bit-position map, and assign the corresponding status or fault code.
Reference: MODBUS map – Section 1, Category 3.

Conversion example: The following example illustrates how TracWater IAAS processes a typical MQTT response message for this category.

Request message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

    255

Conversion:

Convert the signed integer to a ‘signed short’ in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

255 == 0000000011111111

Description: Used for configuration or short-range numerical values (e.g. brush interval).
Conversion Method: Convert the 16-bit signed integer to binary, reverse byte order (BA → AB), interpret as an unsigned short, then apply scaling if specified.
Reference: MODBUS map – Section 1, Category 4.

Conversion Example: The following example illustrates how TracWater IAAS processes a typical MQTT response message for this category.

Request message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "type": 1,

  "device_id": "sonde",

  "timeout": 1,

  "server_id": 1,

  "function": 3,

  "register_number": 3585,

  "register_count": 1

}



Response message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "success": true,

  "data": [

    1280

  ]

}



Conversion:

Convert the signed integer to an ‘signed short’ in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

1280 == 0000010100000000

Reverse the byte order in the 16bit binary number

00000101 00000000 = 00000000 00000101 = 0000000000000101

Convert the reversed 16bit binary number to an “Unsigned short”. Reference link.

0000000000000101 = 5

Description: Used where the register stores a single signed short integer requiring scaling to engineering units (e.g. battery voltage).
Conversion Method: Interpret the signed short, convert to decimal, then multiply by the scaling factor defined in the MODBUS map.
Reference: MODBUS map – Section 1, Category 5.

Conversion example: The following example illustrates how TracWater IAAS processes a typical MQTT response message for this category.

Request message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "type": 1,

  "device_id": "sonde",

  "timeout": 1,

  "server_id": 2,

  "function": 3,

  "register_number": 33,

  "register_count": 1

}



Response message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "success": true,

  "data": [1133]

}



Conversion:

The value in the data field is a “short”. Convert it to an “unsigned short” or “UNIT16”.

1133 == 1133

Apply the “Multiplier” (see table).

1133 x 0.01 = 11.33

Description: Used for configuration values expressed as hexadecimal codes (e.g. startup modes, operational flags).
Conversion Method: Convert the signed short to 16-bit binary, extract the first byte, convert to hexadecimal, and match against the defined code map to determine the parameter state.
Reference: MODBUS map – Section 1, Category 6.

Conversion example: The following example illustrates how TracWater IAAS processes a typical MQTT response message for this category.

Request message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "type": 1,

  "device_id": "sonde",

  "timeout": 1,

  "server_id": 1,

  "function": 3,

  "register_number": 6913,

  "register_count": 1

}

Response message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "success": true,

  "data": [

    257

  ]

}



Conversion:

Convert the signed integer to a “signed short” in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

257 == 0000000100000001

Extract the first 8 bits as a standalone binary number.

0000000100000001 = 00000001

Convert the 8bit binary number to a 4-digit hex number.

00000001 = 0x0001

Look up the Hex number in the “Code map” column

Description: Used for paired firmware or hardware version numbers where each byte encodes a minor and major version integer.
Conversion Method: Reverse byte order, split each byte, convert to integers, and concatenate with a decimal separator (e.g. “3.11”, “2.7”).
Reference: MODBUS map – Section 1, Category 7.

Conversion example: The following example illustrates how TracWater IAAS processes a typical MQTT response message for this category.

Request message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "type": 1,

  "device_id": "sonde",

  "timeout": 1,

  "server_id": 1,

  "function": 3,

  "register_number": 1793,

  "register_count": 2

}



Response message:

{

  "cookie": 1,

  "success": true,

  "data": [

    256,

    262

  ]

}



Conversion:

MQTT response message contains a field named “data”, which contains a list of 2 “signed integers”.

Convert the 1st signed integer to a “signed short” in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

256 == 0000000100000000

Take the 16bit binary number from the previous step, and reverse the byte order.

0000000100000000 = 00000000 00000001 = 0000000000000001

Extract the first set of 8 bits as a standalone binary number, and convert to an integer.

0000000000000001 > 00000000

00000000 = 0

Extract the second set of 8 bits as a standalone binary number, and convert to an integer.

0000000000000001 > 00000001

00000001 = 1

Concatenate the first integer with a “.” character, then append the second integer to form the Hardware version number:

0 + . + 1 = 0.1

Convert the 2nd signed integer to a “signed short” in 16bit binary notation. Reference link.

262 == 0000000100000110

Take the 16bit binary number from the previous step, and reverse the byte order.

0000000100000110 = 00000110  00000001 = 0000011000000001

Extract the first set of 8 bits as a standalone binary number, and convert to an integer.

0000011000000001 > 00000110

00000110 = 6

Extract the second set of 8 bits as a standalone binary number, and convert to an integer.

0000000000000001 > 00000001

00000001 = 1

Concatenate the first integer with a “.” character, then append the second integer to form the Software version number:

6 + . + 1 = 6.1

Each conversion step includes validation checks to ensure data integrity:

Register count validation – confirm the number of registers matches the expected count for the conversion type.

Byte-order consistency – verify correct endian handling (Big Endian vs Little Endian).

Range validation – compare converted values against predefined min/max limits.

Exception logging – any conversion failures are logged in TracWater IAAS with associated cookie ID and timestamp.
This section defines the raw data assets that provide the foundation for all TracWater IAAS processed data.

A raw data asset is any digital measurement, status, or operational value captured directly from a TracWater-connected device or system and stored in a TracWater database prior to any transformation or analytical processing.
Raw data assets include, but are not limited to:

text: Instrument outputs received through the MQTT MODBUS Gateway (see Sections 4.9 and 4.10).
Direct serial or network feeds from other field devices (e.g. SDI-12 sondes, pulse counters, analog converters).
System telemetry such as gateway signal strength, battery voltage, internal temperature, and operational heartbeat.
External data integrations (e.g. Bureau of Meteorology rainfall feeds, third-party SCADA values, or customer-provided datasets).

content.text: Each raw data source is uniquely identified within TracWater IAAS by its Device ID and Data Tag metadata, ensuring unambiguous traceability from acquisition through to processed outputs.

All raw data are:

Timestamped upon entry into the TracWater IAAS message broker or ingestion pipeline.

Logged into the time-series database in their original numeric or textual form (decoded but unmodified).

Associated with metadata describing unit, precision, and sensor provenance (from the product’s data specification).

Immutable — once recorded, raw values are not altered, only superseded by later measurements.
The TracWater IAAS Processed Data Specification references these raw data sources to describe how each is transformed, averaged, normalised, or aggregated for visualisation, analytics, and reporting.

Each processed data definition must include:

The originating raw data source (Device ID + Data Tag).

The transformation function or rule applied.

The target dataset or dashboard where the processed data are presented.
